subject: Re: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: The fact that it has no assertions isn t the problem. The test is meaningless, assertions or no. Instead: public void testSomeThing() { fail( Not yet
messageBody:
The fact that it has no assertions isn't the problem. The test is
meaningless, assertions or no.

Instead:

public void testSomeThing() {
fail("Not yet implemented!");
}

No framework, good or bad, can stop people from doing silly thing. Your
example was a silly thing. Developers should not be silly when they can
avoid it.

What about this test:

public void testSomeThing() {
for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { assertTrue(true); }
}

"See? I have over 1000 assertions! I'm way ahead of you guys! What's your
excuse?!"

If you measure X and say, "More X is good," then all you get is more X.

Thanks.
J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>

To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
cc:
Subject: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts





The following test case has no assertions...

        public void testSomeThing()
        {
                // fill in this code someday... in the meantime,
                // give everyone a false sense of security because
                // this counts as a passed test.
        }

...should I be worried that this test isn't good enough?
